unit.title: Grammar Workshop II: Clauses, Punctuation, and Editing
unit.overview: Learners consolidate grammar for clear writing and speaking: independent/dependent clauses, compound and complex sentences, and British punctuation (commas, semicolons, colons, quotation marks). The unit includes a hands‑on editing challenge and a short skit project to apply grammar in dialogue. Lessons are short and gamified to reduce fatigue, with AI feedback and XP hooks.
competencies: Identify independent and dependent clauses; form compound and complex sentences.
Use coordinating and subordinating conjunctions accurately (for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so; because, although, when, if).
Apply British punctuation rules for commas, semicolons, colons, and quotation marks in dialogue.
Edit paragraphs to correct fragments, run‑ons, and misused punctuation.
Write and perform a short skit with clear dialogue punctuation and stage directions.
values_morals: Clarity and honesty in communication build trust.
Teamwork and respect while scripting and performing.

lessons.title: Clauses & Sentence Types
objectives: Build simple, compound, and complex sentences.

vocabulary.definition: A group of words with a subject and verb that can stand alone.
A clause that cannot stand alone and begins with a subordinator (e.g., because, although).
One independent clause + at least one dependent clause.

lessons.moral_link: Structure your ideas so others can follow your meaning.

content_blocks.body: Examples: Simple—'Ama sings.' Compound—'Ama sings, and Kofi plays.' Complex—'Although Ama is shy, she sings well.'
If a sentence begins with a dependent clause, add a comma after it in British English style.

classify.prompt: Mark each as Independent (I) or Dependent (D).

ai_task.prompt: Combine: 'The bell rang.' + 'We stayed to tidy the hall.' Create (1) a compound and (2) a complex sentence.

lessons.title: Conjunctions: Coordinating & Subordinating
objectives: Use coordinating conjunctions (FANBOYS) with comma rules.
Use subordinators (because, although, when, if, while) to show relationships.

vocabulary.definition: Joins equal parts (for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so).
Opens a dependent clause (because, although, when…).

lessons.moral_link: Choose words that show fair and honest connections.

content_blocks.caption: Conjunction map: cause, contrast, time, condition.

content_blocks.body: Comma rule: use a comma before a coordinating conjunction joining two independent clauses.

items.text: We wanted to help, ___ we were tired.
___ it rained, the team cleaned the hall.
We will start ___ the bell rings.

ai_task.prompt: Write three complex sentences showing cause, contrast, and time using 'because', 'although', and 'when'.

lessons.title: Punctuation Power: Commas, Semicolons, Colons, Quotes
objectives: Use commas for lists, clause openers, and before coordinating conjunctions in compound sentences.
Use semicolons to join closely related independent clauses; use colons to introduce lists/explanations.
Punctuate dialogue with British quotation marks and punctuation placement.

vocabulary.definition: A punctuation mark (;) linking two related independent clauses.
A punctuation mark (:) introducing a list or explanation.
Often single quotes for direct speech; punctuation usually outside unless part of the quote.

lessons.moral_link: Good punctuation helps you speak truth clearly on the page.

content_blocks.body: Semicolon: 'The pitch was muddy; we cleaned the hall instead.' Colon: 'Bring these items: gloves, brooms, and bags.'
British quotes: 'We will help,' Ama said. Yaw replied, 'That is kind.'

content_blocks.caption: When to use comma, semicolon, colon, and quotes.

error_hunt.text: We were ready but the rain was heavy we waited however we still started. 'let’s go', said yaw.
tasks: Fix run‑ons using semicolons and commas with FANBOYS.
Fix quotation marks and capitalisation (British style).
error_hunt.solution_hint: Split or link clauses: ';', ', and'. Capitalise dialogue starts; single quotes are standard in UK style.

options: Bring: gloves, and brooms, and bags.
Bring these items: gloves, brooms, and bags.
I like reading; I also enjoy writing.

lessons.title: Editing Challenge: Fragments & Run‑ons
objectives: Detect and fix sentence fragments and run‑on sentences.

vocabulary.definition: A group of words punctuated as a sentence but lacking a complete thought.
Two or more independent clauses improperly joined.

lessons.moral_link: Finish what you start—complete ideas show responsibility.

content_blocks.body: Strategies: add missing subject/verb, join clauses with semicolons or conjunctions, or split into sentences.

ai_task.prompt: Paste a paragraph of your writing. Ask the AI to flag fragments and run‑ons, explain the issue, and offer two corrected versions.

options: The rain stopped, and we played.
We played when the rain stopped.
Although it rained, we stayed inside.

lessons.title: Project: Write & Perform a Skit
objectives: Draft a 1–2 page skit script with clear stage directions and correctly punctuated dialogue.
Perform the skit (60–90 seconds per group) with clear pronunciation and respectful teamwork.

vocabulary.definition: Instructions in a script about actions, setting, or tone.

lessons.moral_link: Use teamwork and honesty to create a performance that uplifts others.

content_blocks.caption: Skit script layout with character names and stage directions.

content_blocks.body: Keep scenes focused; use conjunctions to link ideas and punctuation to guide readers.

scaffold: Scene 2 (rising action with clear dialogue punctuation)

speaking_task.prompt: Perform your skit (group audio/video 60–90 seconds). Speak clearly; respect turn‑taking.

options: A complete sentence that stands alone.
A clause that needs an independent clause to be complete.

quiz_mcq.q: Choose the correctly punctuated compound sentence.
options: We cleaned the lab, and we labelled the shelves.
We cleaned the lab and, we labelled the shelves.
Ama practised; because the test was near.
Ama practised; she wanted to improve.

quiz_mcq.q: Which sentence uses a colon correctly?
options: Bring these items: gloves, brooms, bags.

quiz_mcq.q: British dialogue punctuation is correct in:

editing_task.prompt: Edit a 120–150 word paragraph to fix fragments, run‑ons, and punctuation (comma/semicolon/colon/quotes) errors. Provide before-and-after versions.

speaking_task.prompt: Record your group’s skit (60–90 seconds). Ensure clear speech, correct dialogue punctuation in the script, and respectful teamwork.

criteria.name: Error Detection
criteria.descriptor: Correctly identifies fragments, run‑ons, and punctuation issues.

criteria.name: Clarity & Flow
criteria.descriptor: Revised text reads smoothly with accurate clause links.

criteria.name: Mechanics (UK)
criteria.descriptor: Correct British quotation, spelling, and punctuation.

criteria.name: Script Quality
criteria.descriptor: Clear structure, correct dialogue punctuation, varied clauses.

criteria.name: Delivery
criteria.descriptor: Audible, paced speech; teamwork and turn‑taking.
